step_by_step_thinking: The newborn presents with symptoms of hyperthyroidism (fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, irritability) and a midline neck swelling (goiter). The mother has a history of Graves' disease, which is associated with TSH receptor antibodies (TRAbs). These antibodies can cross the placenta, causing neonatal hyperthyroidism. Document [0] and [13] confirm that transplacental TRAbs are the cause of neonatal hyperthyroidism in this context. Other options (thyroid peroxidase antibodies, viral infection, opiate use) do not align with the clinical presentation or maternal history.
